item.title: Coronavirus: UK death toll passes Italy to be highest in Europe
item.description: The figure of 29,427 deaths is "a massive tragedy", the foreign secretary says, but steers clear of comparisons.

item.title: Coronavirus: Virgin Atlantic to cut 3,000 jobs and quit Gatwick
item.description: The airline will axe a third of its workforce in response to the "severe impact" of coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Prof Neil Ferguson quits government role after 'undermining' lockdown
item.description: Prof Neil Ferguson, who advised ministers on coronavirus, says he "made an error of judgement".

item.title: Shop 'stabbing': Murder arrest after Penygraig Co-op incident
item.description: One person dies and three are hurt following the incident in south Wales.

item.title: Coronavirus: Nurse and parents with Covid-19 die weeks apart
item.description: Lillian, 81, and Maurice Dunnington, 85, died days apart, and just two weeks after their son Keith.

item.title: Coronavirus: Robin Swann 'shocked' at images of packed flight
item.description: Aer Lingus is boosting capacity on its Belfast-Heathrow route after a photo showed a packed aircraft.

item.title: Water buffalo attack leaves one dead and two hurt in Usk
item.description: The 57-year-old man was declared dead at the scene and another man was critically injured.

item.title: Covid-19: Fourteen covid-related deaths at Glengormley care home
item.description: The patients, who all died from covid-related symptoms, were residents of Glenabbey Manor.

item.title: Coronavirus: White House plans to disband virus task force
item.description: The vice-president says the task force may wind down by the end of May or early June.

item.title: Disney suffers $1.4bn hit due to coronavirus
item.description: Lockdowns have forced the company to close its theme parks and has hurt advertising.

item.title: Coronavirus by air: The spread of Covid-19 in the Middle East
item.description: An investigation by BBC News Arabic has found how one Iranian airline contributed to the spread of the virus around the Middle East.

item.title: Daniel Radcliffe delights fans with Harry Potter video reading
item.description: The star returns to the world of Harry Potter by reading the first chapter from the first book.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: UK death toll Europe's worst, and adviser quits
item.description: The news that the UK has the highest number of coronavirus deaths in Europe features in Wednesday's papers.

item.title: The Met Gala ball is off - but stars dressed to impress anyway
item.description: The fashion extravaganza was axed, but some stars revealed their outfits anyway, and fans joined in.

item.title: Dame Judi Dench becomes British Vogue's oldest cover star at 85
item.description: The Oscar-winner says she hopes "a great deal of kindness comes out of this" current global crisis.

item.title: ‘The nursery I run may not survive’
item.description: Thousands of nurseries and childminders may shut permanently due to the pandemic, research suggests.

item.title: Captain Tom's video message for Felixstowe fundraiser aged 101
item.description: He wishes good luck to a fellow centenarian aiming to support the NHS with a walking challenge.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your pictures of lockdown at home
item.description: Our readers reveal the new normal of their life during the coronavirus crisis.

item.title: Life inside the UK's first 'TikTok house'
item.description: These six creators moved in together to make viral TikTok videos.

item.title: How coronavirus restrictions have changed UK beaches
item.description: Buckets and spades have gone from England's beaches, replaced with wildlife and sand art.

item.title: Coronavirus: When might Hollywood reopen for business?
item.description: Cast and crews might have to quarantine together in the future when filming begins again.

item.title: Coronavirus: How amateur radio is connecting people during lockdown
item.description: More people are taking to the airwaves to stay connected. What's the appeal of amateur radio?

item.title: Coronavirus: Thanking healthcare workers worldwide
item.description: Some of the ways that people have expressed thanks to workers on the frontline against Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: NHS staff to help find out why people get sick
item.description: NHS workers are donating blood samples to find out why some of them contract Covid-19 when others don't.

item.title: The groundbreaking way to search lungs for signs of Covid-19
item.description: Artificial intelligence technology is being rapidly deployed worldwide to help tackle Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: How to open a hairdressers after lockdown
item.description: Hairdressers can reopen after Germany relaxes its lockdown but there is a long list of rules.

item.title: Coronation Street: Coercive control is 'all of our business'
item.description: Producers say Geoff's abuse of Yasmeen in the soap is a "tough watch", but sends a crucial message.

item.title: Coronavirus: The lure of mafia money during the crisis
item.description: Italian businesses are crumbling in the crisis, leaving a familiar "benefactor" to fill the vacuum.

item.title: Coronavirus: Traffic 'reaching early 1970s levels'
item.description: The lockdown means roads are far quieter than normal, but does driving feel like it did decades ago?

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Is lockdown good for your heart?
item.description: Why do fewer people seem to be having heart attacks and strokes? One theory is that the lockdown lifestyle is healthy.

item.title: How socially distanced stars are still making TV dramas in a crisis
item.description: Broadcasters find ways to film new shows - but screen dramas won't return to normal for a long time.

item.title: Single, pregnant and self-isolating
item.description: Carla Fitzgerald explains what it's like to be pregnant and single during lockdown.

item.title: 'There is no easy solution' - inside sport's £700m 'hole'
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic could cost cricket, football and rugby union almost £700m combined in the UK, leading figures have said.

item.title: Return of sport would 'lift the nation', says government
item.description: Restarting sport in Britain would "lift the spirits of the nation" amid the coronavirus crisis, foreign secretary Dominic Raab says.

item.title: England and Scotland players make 'significant' donation to NHS
item.description: Players from the England and Scotland national teams make "substantial" donations to the NHS.

item.title: Short halves in football an option - PFA boss Taylor
item.description: Professional Footballers' Association chief executive Gordon Taylor says halves of less than 45 minutes are being considered when football resumes.

item.title: Tour de France to start in August - with Giro and Vuelta to overlap
item.description: The Tour de France will start on 29 August, with the Giro d'Italia and Vuelta a Espana overlapping during October, the UCI announces.

item.title: Formula 1 bosses make final budget offer to teams
item.description: Formula 1 bosses have made a final offer to teams of a sliding scale budget cap reducing from $145m to $130m over the next three years.

item.title: Ramsey to Man Utd in Pogba swap deal - gossip
item.description: Paul Pogba could return to Juventus with Aaron Ramsey moving to Old Trafford, Arsenal may need to sell six players to cover Pepe fee, Willian to Spurs, plus more.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can you compare the UK with Italy?
item.description: The UK has passed Italy's death toll but it's hard to make direct comparisons.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will it be safe to fly again?
item.description: Air passenger numbers have plummeted since the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work and is my data safe?
item.description: Millions in the UK will soon be asked to download an app that helps to limit coronavirus spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: When will it end and how?
item.description: What is the path to normality as coronavirus leaves countries in lockdown?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the UK's test, track and trace strategy?
item.description: A guide to the three key parts of the government's coronavirus strategy after lockdowns are eased.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Inventive routes back to normal life
item.description: Bubbles, vending machines and staggered school days - some methods are more innovative than others.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: When will we have a drug to treat it?
item.description: There are no drugs proven to help doctors treat the disease, but work is under way around the world.

item.title: Coronavirus: Why did the UK need 100,000 tests a day?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: When will we have one?
item.description: We answer some of the big questions about vaccines and how long one for coronavirus could take.

item.title: Coronavirus: Should the public wear face masks?
item.description: There is growing discussion about the potential benefits of the general public wearing masks.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Emotional abuse: ‘My fiance seemed perfect - but he wanted to control me’
item.description: An actress who became engaged to an older and more successful actor, describes six months of emotional abuse.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I never thought I'd be so proud to sell bread and butter'
item.description: Laura McLellan felt humbled when she and her team of checkout operators were told they were key workers.

item.title: 'Nobody told us about the coronavirus pandemic'
item.description: Before setting sail around the world, Elena and Ryan told their families not to give them bad news.

item.title: Coronavirus: Protecting the 'one in a million' girl
item.description: Bex Price's family went into isolation early as coronavirus would almost certainly kill her.

item.title: Coronavirus: Making face masks feels 'like the war effort'
item.description: Thousands of people are producing cloth masks, despite UK authorities saying they are unnecessary.

item.title: Coronavirus journey: The 'last cruise ship on Earth' finally comes home
item.description: From political storms to presidential pleas, it has been quite a journey for the MSC Magnifica.

item.title: The tiny premature baby who fought off coronavirus
item.description: Peyton Maguire from Lanarkshire is one of the youngest Covid-19 patients in the UK.

item.title: How Typhoid Mary left a trail of scandal and death
item.description: The chilling story of an Irish immigrant cook who brought typhoid to well-to-do families in New York.

item.title: Coronavirus: Grandmas' top tips to get through lockdown
item.description: We've asked Grannies from around the world for their advice on staying positive.

item.title: A coronavirus survivor's story: 'I touched death'
item.description: Elizabeth says she feels lucky to be alive after falling seriously ill with the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Wacky and wonderful scrubs for NHS workers
item.description: Hundreds of volunteers are making scrubs of all different designs and colours for doctors and nurses.
